DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Results Domain Lesion Fludeoxyglucose F-18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The scaled score that corresponds to the FDG PET uptake in a lesion.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Results Domain Lesion Fludeoxyglucose F-18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A findings domain that represents quantitative measurements and/or qualitative assessments of the tumors identified in the TU domain._A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part._The radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET), a diagnostic imaging procedure._A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered._The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A findings domain that represents quantitative measurements and/or qualitative assessments of the tumors identified in the TU domain.

Concepts.definition: A findings domain that represents quantitative measurements and/or qualitative assessments of the tumors identified in the TU domain.

Property.preferredName: Lesion Fludeoxyglucose F-18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake
Property.preferredDefinition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.:The radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET), a diagnostic imaging procedure.:A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.:The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.

Concepts.definition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

A positron-emitting radiopharmaceutical containing radioactive 2-deoxy-2-[18F] fluoro-D-glucose. With similar cell uptake as glucose (high in tumor cells), fludeoxyglucose F 18 is not dephosphorylated and further metabolized. (NCI04)

A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredName: Fludeoxyglucose F-18 Positron Emission Tomography Uptake Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The radioactive form of glucose used in positron emission tomography (PET), a diagnostic imaging procedure._A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered._The absorption by a tissue of some substance, food material, mineral, etc., and its permanent or temporary retention._An ordered reference standard used to measure incremental changes.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A prominent or noticeable characteristic.: A process of becoming larger, more numerous, more important, or more likely.: The examination of two or more people or things in order to detect similarities and differences.: Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

A process of becoming larger, more numerous, more important, or more likely.
The examination of two or more people or things in order to detect similarities and differences.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.

A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.
Combine together into a single unit, group, or sample.
